channel.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
channel.description:
I could pass a preliminary test... [url=http://up.ht/ug1fqW]http://up.ht/ug1fqW[/url]
EDIT: replaced download link with a better copy provided by "veer" in the comments below. Thanks dude!

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

eh, i’m getting confused now.

what i was trying to corner you into thinking but did a bad job of was - every single time there’s an update (an iteration) the shortest path you have computed for each node is no longer guaranteed to be the shortest path. gates may have opened or gates may have closed causing the shortest path to be different. so you have to recompute the shortest path each and every iteration for each and every node until you come up with the final shortest path. this is precisely what an algorithm like bellman-ford does.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

It’s not looping infinitely at all; if done doing an iterative implementation of a breadth-first search, it’s just going to be more squares to check. If a cycle is a dead-end, it won’t stop the algorithm from solving the issue (it’s not depth-first).
This however does not build on problem 2; the tidbit about what values >= 1 denote is here:

The game is being changed to include gates that open and close at regular intervals. The character should be able to get to the destination in the shortest time using the gates within the map. Each gate starts off open and will close after x updates then reopen x updates later. Gates close and open after the character moves each call of updates. The character must never end up on a gate as it closes.
As you can see, there is no place here for the speeds as in problem 2 to be used in problem 3; it never mentions them in the specification, nor in the examples given. This means the graph isn't weighted and therefore a breadth-first search approach works fine.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

ok, now it becomes a problem of detecting whether or not you’ll even be able to pass the gate. what’s to stop it from looping infinitely in question 3 example 1?

also, keep in mind that each problem builds on the one before it. “values of 1 and higher denote the value of x in
the above description of the gates”. thus, this can’t be a breadth first search because the weights aren’t guaranteed to be unit.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Determining the state of a gate is important for traversing, though I now see what you’re talking about. I can’t implement the foresight you mention but I do think there is a solution if you introduce a new decision into the game tree, namely the ability to stay in one place.
Well currently you have at most 4 edges from any square i.e. one in each cardinal direction (if each is open). You could probably adjust this so that every square also has an edge to themselves, meaning at most 5. The rest of the algorithm would remain untouched.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

but all you’ve done is determine whether or not a gate is currently open. how does your algorithm know that, if you wait around on the same square for a while, the gate can open back up?

see question 3 example 3

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Back to question 3… I think I found something roughly equivalent to lazily construct a game tree. Its very similar to problem 1; I imagine using a breadth-first search here too.
The only added hurdle is that you need to know square state while traversing it. You can very cheaply find the state of these temporal squares given that the depth of your search (i.e. the steps taken since the beginning) would be the number of updates elapsed:

int square = timemap[x][y]; boolean open = square > 0 ? (depth % (square * 2) < depth) : (square == 0);
or something of that sort.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

“I think you may be misunderstanding the exercise… squares may or may not contain solid walls. Those that do are themselves completely untraversable. Walls do not however exist in between squares.”

damn straight. haha, you’re right it’s undirected, but bellman-ford can still be used if for every out-edge between two nodes, you have an in-edge between those two.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Yeah, the scaling factor I used of 10 was just for show. Using the plain reciprocal would work fine… the ratios (and therefore order) are invariant and they’re the only things that matter.
Has anyone here tried to get a job at jagex? We have enough talent I’d imagine.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

oh i see what you’re saying, but the weight is the speed. so you can just take the reciprocal of everything i.e. w(6) = 1/6 and w(2) = 1/2

yea, that works, too. my bad. i think they just want you to know that you have to map the weights in the speedmap to something that works.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

I appreciated your summary of how Bellman-Ford worked.
Maybe I’m thinking of the problem incorrectly, but surely the weight could simply be inversely proportional to the speed… for example say w(s) determines the weight given speed:
w(s | s != 0) = 10/s
w(0) = some special constant used to signify an untraversable square. In this case we wouldn’t be trying to use these squares, anyways.

[code]int speedmap[][][/code] An array of arbitrary size in which a value of zero denotes a solid wall and the numbers 1 to 10 denote how easy a section of floor is to cross. E.g. map squares with a value of 6 can be traversed at twice the speed of squares with a value of 3. Assume that the map is rectangular and not larger than 128 by 128.

The ratios are correctly inverted under this transformation of speed to weight. So, for example, with speeds 6 and 2:
w(6) = 1.666…
w(2) = 5

So…
6/2 = 3 which makes sense; traversing a square at speed 6 is indeed 3 times faster than with speed 2.
w(6)/w(2) = 1/3 which also makes sense; it takes 1/3 of the time to cross a square at speed 6 relative to at speed 2.

These weights aren’t negative and work according to the problem specification, so why can’t A* just be used?

Moving on, the first problem also deals with walls:

[code]boolean solidmap[][][/code] A map of arbitrary size where true denotes a solid wall and false denotes an empty square. Assume that the map is rectangular and not larger than 128 by 128.

I think you may be misunderstanding the exercise… squares may or may not contain solid walls. Those that do are themselves completely untraversable. Walls do not however exist in between squares.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

you have to negate all the weights on purpose to solve it.

think of it as redefining the problem to a negative speed is faster than a positive speed. so a speed of -6 is faster than a speed of -2. you end up having to compute the shortest distance for each node every time (relaxing all edges) because your shortest distance assumptions aren’t guaranteed to be correct until you run through each node the number of nodes minus one times.

also, directed and undirected are pretty much the same, all you’re saying is that there’s an edge from u to v and an edge from v to u

also, “in which a value of zero
denotes a solid wall” speedmap is your adjacency matrix list… how is this not a directed graph? the first problem is undirected, though but then they added walls.

EDIT: the first problem has walls, too. i just assumed it didn’t.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Why would edge weights be negative in the first place…? Also, isn’t Bellman-Ford particularly used for directed graphs? I don’t think either of these are concerns.

For picking a heuristic, surely you could just use something like Manhattan distance…

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

almost… A* doesn’t work on negative edge weights. in addition, what would your heuristic function be?

the second problem is bellman-ford. a route can’t be found if there is a negative cycle (bellman-ford takes care of this problem, too)…

fuck the third.

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?

item.title: Think you can work for Jagex?
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[b]Question 1[/b] A simple top down 2D game features characters that move around a grid. Every time game update is called, a character checks to see if he is on his destination square and if he is not, the simpleroute function is called to provide him with the next step that he is required to take, in order to reach the destination in the fewest moves possible. Write the following function:

Parameters:

A map of arbitrary size where true denotes a solid wall and false denotes an empty square. Assume that the map is rectangular and not larger than 128 by 128.

The x,y position of the character where cx is their x position and cy is their y position.

The x,y destination of the character where dx is the x position and dy is the y position

Return:

The map position that the character should move to next where nextstep[0] is the x and nextstep[1] is the y. If no route can be found, nextstep should return the character’s current position.

static int[] simpleroute( boolean solidmap[][] , int cx , int cy , int dx , int dy ) { int nextstep[] = new int[2]; //Your Code Here return nextstep; }


A simple breadth-first search would indeed work here.
[b]Question 2[/b]

To make the game more interesting different types of floor have been added to the map that
allow the player to move at different speeds across them. Also it has been seen that calling
simpleroute every update slows the game down a lot. It would be much faster if the whole
route were sent all at once when a new destination is created. The new speedroute function
takes a speed map of the whole level and returns a list of the positions through which the
player will move that will reach the destination in the fastest time possible.
Write the following function:

Parameters:

An array of arbitrary size in which a value of zero denotes a solid wall and the numbers 1 to 10 denote how easy a section of floor is to cross. E.g. map squares with a value of 6 can be traversed at twice the speed of squares with a value of 3. Assume that the map is rectangular and not larger than 128 by 128.

Return:

An list of positions of the form x0, y0, x1, y1, x2, y2, …, xn, yn where x0, y0 is the first step in the whole route going through to xn, yn which will be the destination. If no route can be found route should be returned as null.

static int[] speedroute( int speedmap[][] , int cx , int cy , int dx , int dy ) { int route[] = null; //Your Code Here return route; }


The second problem is just a single-pair shortest path problem over a weighted graph… the weight would just needs to be inversely proportional to speed, and then an algorithm like A* will work fine.
[b]Question 3[/b]

The game is being changed to include gates that open and close at regular intervals. The character should be able to get to the destination in the shortest time using the gates within the map. Each gate starts off open and will close after x updates then reopen x updates later. Gates close and open after the character moves each call of updates. The character must never end up on a gate as it closes. Write the following function:

Parameters:

An array of arbitrary size where -1 denotes and empty area, 0 denotes a solid wall and values of 1 and higher denote the value of x in the above description of the gates. Assume that the map is rectangular and not larger than 128 by 128.

static int[] temporalroute( int timemap[][] , int cx , int cy , int dx , int dy ) { int route[] = null; //Your Code Here return route; }


For the third, I imagine this is isn’t the best way to solve the problem, but you could lazily construct a decision tree that is augmented with the state of gates and do a deepening graph search until the goal state is reached… I figured something like how to solve bloxors. What do you think?

EDIT: For a faster, less annoying download of the document… http://up.ht/ug1fqW

Read full topic
item.source: Think you can work for Jagex?
